New Yugoslav Leader Inaugurates A New Era Vojislav Kostunica, whose shoeleather campaign and reputation for honesty made him the beneficiary of a nation fed up with Slobodan Milosevic, stood before Yugoslavs as their new leader. Mr. Kostunica won presidential elections Sept. 24 but has been put in office by a popular revolution.
President Clinton and European leaders seem likely to remove most sanctions on trade and investment with Yugoslavia in coming days.
INTERNATIONAL

New Yugoslav Leader Inaugurates A New Era Vojislav Kostunica, whose shoeleather campaign and reputation for honesty made him the beneficiary of a nation fed up with Slobodan Milosevic, stood before Yugoslavs as their new leader. Mr. Kostunica won presidential elections Sept. 24 but has been put in office by a popular revolution.
President Clinton and European leaders seem likely to remove most sanctions on trade and investment with Yugoslavia in coming days.
Washington is celebrating the downfall of Slobodan Milosevic, a man who for years delighted in defying, befuddling and belittling his far more powerful foes.
President Jiang Zemin of China, one of Mr. Milosevic's staunchest supporters during last year's NATO campaign against Yugoslavia, sent ''heartfelt congratulations'' to the newly elected president.

Barak's Issues an Ultimatum As the violence spread into Lebanon, Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel gave Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, 48 hours to restrain protests before Israeli troops would be authorized to use ''all available means'' to quell the riots.
Hundreds of Palestinians overran, ransacked and burned Joseph's Tomb, a site considered sacred to some Jews, hours after it was vacated by Israeli troops.
The United Nations Security Council approved a resolution condemning ''excessive use of force'' against the Palestinians. The United States, which could have vetoed the measure, abstained.
NATIONAL

Candidates Are Working To Close the Gender Gap Vice President Al Gore is safely ahead among women, who since at least 1980 have tended to vote liberal and Democratic, but over all, men prefer Gov. George W. Bush -- in one poll likening him to a Maserati and Mr. Gore to a Volvo. Each candidate is trying to bridge the gender gap by tinkering with his image.
Vice President Al Gore denied the Republicans' contention that he often embellishes his record.
The candidates are presenting voters with an unusually stark choice over the kind of people they would select as federal judges.
John H. Chafee, the revered Rhode Island senator who died last October, remains a presence in the closely contested race to fill his seat.
Auction Houses' Secrets An executive's fall from favor led to the unveiling of years of price fixing between Sotheby's and Christie's.
'Morning After' Program Several states are testing a program to provide women ''morning after'' pills to end pregnancies, without requiring that they speak to a doctor.
Park Faces Opposition A proposed $100 million theme park at Stone Mountain, Ga., is facing opposition. Some are concerned about preservation, others about depicting the South's complicated past.
Battle Over Wildlife Refuge A wildlife refuge in Alaska is at the center of political battle. It is remote and pristine, but it also rests atop a vast, untapped oil reserve.
NEW YORK/REGION

New Jersey Senate Candidate Struggling for Campaign Funds The race to succeed United States Senator Frank R. Lautenberg is coming down to a stark question -- will the Republican candidate, Bob Franks, have enough money to run a credible race against his Democratic opponent, Jon S. Corzine?

Lazio Defends Ads Representative Rick A. Lazio declared that he had a ''complete commitment to campaign finance reform'' and had not breached the deal with Hillary Rodham Clinton to restrict campaign spending by accepting $1.8 million from Washington Republicans for television advertisements.

Cemetery Seeks Legal Relief Facing potentially costly suits over a crumbling burial hill built on demolition debris, Cypress Hills Cemetery has filed a bankruptcy petition. The move is intended to stave off legal actions brought on by the construction and disintegration of the hill.
OBITUARIES
Saburo Sakai A Japanese fighter pilot in World War II who said he shot down 64 Allied planes, including one of each type the United States flew, he was 84.

Sidney R. Yates A congressman from Chicago for nearly half a century who battled for government support for the arts and built a reputation as a die-hard liberal Democrat and formidable vote-getter, he was 91.
